messageBody:
Hi "sponge",

On 9/21/07, synapticsponge <synapticsponge@...> wrote:
> I'm just learning JUnit so I can apply it to my Client/Server system.
> I need to send a command to the server, wait for a brief amount of
> time, then check the state of the Server. Whenever I try to call the
> wait() method in one of my tests, I get an IllegalMonitorStateException.
>
> How can I wait in JUnit?

The javadocs for IllegalMonitorStateException explain what the problem
is. In plain English, it means that you're trying to invoke
Object#wait() on an object that you don't have a synchronization lock
on. In other words, you need to call wait() inside a synchronized
block.

As such, "waiting" in JUnit is no different from "waiting" in any Java
code. The same rules and idioms apply--JUnit doesn't really change the
game in any way.

Having said that, you can make life easier for yourself by designing
your multi-threaded code to be testable. In fact, [plug alert] my new
book has a whole chapter on test-driving unpredictable code such as
concurrent programs. It's a science in itself and one chapter doesn't
quite do justice for concurrent programming, but I do think it's a
good place to start.

Lasse
